Some years ago, a website highlighted the risks of public check-ins on social media. The site argued that by sharing your whereabouts, you're not just telling friends where you are, but also advertising your presence to everyone, including people you may not want to meet. This confirmed the growing awareness that there are downsides to sharing our lives online. While the internet offers many opportunities to share our thoughts and experiences with a global audience, it also poses risks. We may share too much, too soon, and regret it later. This is a lesson that pioneers of the internet, known as bloggers, learned many years ago.

In the early days of the web, these pioneers shared their personal stories, photos, and experiences online. They faced challenges, such as losing friends and jobs, and dealing with the consequences of their online actions. They paved the way for the rest of us, showing us what can happen when we share too much online.

Justin Hall, a 19-year-old student, was one of the first bloggers. He started posting his personal thoughts and experiences online in 1994. He shared his life with the world, including photos and art. His blog became popular, and people came to see what he was up to. However, he faced challenges, including losing his home page and dealing with the consequences of his online actions.

Heather Armstrong, a young web worker, also shared her life online. She wrote about her job and personal life on her blog, but her employer found out and fired her. This is an example of the "online distribution effect," where people feel they can say things online that they wouldn't say in person. However, our online lives are connected to our real lives, and we must be careful what we share.

Armstrong learned a valuable lesson and eventually started a new blog focused on her family life. She is now a successful "mommy blogger" who uses her writing to support her family. Her story teaches us that while the internet allows us to share our thoughts and experiences, we must be mindful of the consequences of our actions.

'A while back, some scientists started a campaign to warn people about a low-budget film called What the Bleep Do We Know? The film combines documentary and drama to show that there's a lot we don't understand about our universe. While it's true that scientists can be a bit arrogant, no one claims to have all the answers. Some scientists felt compelled to issue public warnings, describing the film as 'atrocious' or 'dangerous'. This sparked curiosity, and I had to see the film for myself. Initially, I didn't understand the fuss, as scientists were simply stating that new discoveries were revealing the universe to be stranger than expected. However, when the film explained these discoveries, I began to see why it was so controversial. For example, it discussed the ability of water molecules to be affected by thought. I had heard of this before, but the film's evidence was limited to pictures of ice crystals changing shape depending on the mood of those around them. While some people find this convincing, scientists require more substantial proof. The film's claims are indeed astonishing, but without concrete evidence, they remain speculative. The real issue is that the film's claims aren't bizarre enough. In reality, discoveries are being made that prove the universe is far stranger than we thought. For instance, astronomers have found evidence of an unknown form of matter and a mysterious force driving the universe's expansion. Similarly, neuroscientists have discovered that our perception of events is delayed by half a second, and anthropologists have identified the birthplace of modern humans. Theories are emerging that link the existence of life on Earth to the fundamental design of the universe. Despite what some might believe, science is far from complete. In fact, we're further away from omniscience than ever. The concepts of chaos and quantum uncertainty have put limits on what we can know. Theories aside, many of us believe the universe is best summed up in one word: incredible.'

Writing novels is a challenging task for me, while writing short stories is a joy. The process of writing novels is like planting a forest, while writing short stories is like tending a garden. Both processes complement each other, creating a complete landscape that I treasure. The trees in the forest provide shade, and the wind rustles the leaves, sometimes turning them a brilliant gold. In the garden, flowers bloom, and their colorful petals attract bees and butterflies, reminding us of the changing seasons. Throughout my writing career, I have alternated between writing novels and short stories. After finishing a novel, I often feel the need to write some short stories, and vice versa. I never write short stories while working on a novel, and never write a novel while working on short stories. The two types of writing may engage different parts of my brain, and it takes time to switch between them. I started writing short stories in the mid-1980s, after publishing two short novels in 1975. At first, it was a challenging experience, but it expanded my creative possibilities and allowed readers to see a new side of me as a writer. One of my early short stories, 'Breaking Waves', was included in my first short-story collection, Tales from Abroad. Writing short stories is appealing because they don't take as long to complete. It usually takes me about a week to draft a short story, although revisions can be ongoing. This is in contrast to writing a novel, which can take a year or two. Writing short stories provides a welcome change of pace and allows me to explore ideas that might not be suitable for a novel. I can create a story from a single idea, word, or image, often allowing the story to unfold spontaneously. I also appreciate that I don't have to worry about failing with short stories. Even experienced writers like F. Scott Fitzgerald and Raymond Carver have not always written masterpieces. I find this reassuring, as it allows me to learn from my mistakes and use them to improve my next story. In fact, I often use my short stories as a way to experiment and learn from my experiences, which helps me when writing novels. Without short stories, I would find writing novels even more challenging. My short stories are like personal mementos, reminders of the emotions and experiences that inspired them. They are like guideposts to my heart, and I am happy to share them with my readers.<|eot_id|>

Science is a complex and multifaceted field that has both improved our lives and posed threats to our existence. It has made significant progress in understanding the natural world, from the smallest particles to the vastness of the universe. However, this progress has not been without controversy, as established theories have been constantly challenged and modified. Scientists have often been driven by a desire to prove their theories, which has led to conflicts and rivalries. Despite this, science has led to numerous breakthroughs and innovations that have transformed our understanding of the world and our ability to manipulate it.

Science has also had a significant impact on society, influencing fields such as medicine, technology, and politics. It has the power to shape our future and determine the kind of world our children will inherit. As such, it is essential that non-scientists understand the implications of scientific advancements and be aware of the potential consequences of scientific discoveries.

From around 2015, major publishers started to notice that ebook sales had stopped growing and in some cases had even decreased. This raised doubts about the long-term potential of ebooks in the publishing industry. Some publishing executives admitted that the hype around ebooks might have led to unwise investments. Despite this, the question of whether ebooks will replace print books still sparks debate. The idea that a new technology will 'kill' an existing one is not new. We have seen this pattern throughout history, from the invention of radio to the rise of digital technologies. Each time, critics have predicted the demise of an old medium, but it often ends up adapting to the new technology.

The idea of the 'death of the book' is not new either. As early as 1894, people speculated that the phonograph would replace books with audiobooks. This pattern of predicting the end of an old medium has happened repeatedly. Movies, radio, television, and smartphones have all been accused of replacing print books, but they have coexisted. The debate about the death of the book is not just about the technology itself, but also about our emotional attachment to it. We form strong bonds with objects like books, TVs, and computers, and the emergence of a new technology makes us adjust to the loss of something familiar.

As technology advances, we often long for what we used to know and have. This is why industries develop around retro products and older technologies. The spread of the printing press, for example, led people to seek out original manuscripts. The shift from silent to sound movies and from analog to digital photography also stimulated nostalgia for the older forms. Similarly, the rise of e-readers led to a new appreciation for the material quality of 'old' books and even their distinctive smell.

This should reassure those who worry about the disappearance of print books. However, the idea of the disappearing medium will continue to be a compelling narrative about the power of technology and our fear of change. One way we make sense of change is by using familiar narrative patterns, such as the story of tragedy and ending. The story of the death of the book is a reminder of our enthusiasm for what lies ahead and our fear of losing parts of our intimate world â€“ and ultimately, of ourselves.

Every day, for a year and a half, I got up at 5:30 am and started my day by writing about how famous people, including artists, writers, and scientists, managed to be creative and productive. I wanted to show how their daily routines, including when they slept, ate, and worked, helped them achieve their goals. By sharing these details, I hoped to provide a new perspective on their personalities and careers.

The idea for this book came to me on a Sunday afternoon when I was supposed to be writing an article, but instead, I was procrastinating by tidying my workspace and making coffee. I started browsing the internet for information on how other writers organized their daily routines and found it fascinating. I realized that there was a need for a book that collected these anecdotes in one place.

I started a blog where I shared these stories, and later, I expanded the collection and researched more thoroughly for this book. I tried to keep the same tone and variety of voices that made the blog popular. I used quotes from the original sources, such as letters, diaries, and interviews, to let my subjects speak for themselves. In some cases, I summarized their routines from secondary sources.

I want to acknowledge the work of the many biographers, journalists, and scholars whose research I built upon. I have listed all my sources in the Notes section, which I hope will also serve as a guide for further reading.

Howard's interest in paleontology began when he was six years old. His family had planned a trip to Spain, but due to a rise in interest rates, they had to cancel it. Instead, they went to the English coast, where Howard found an ammonite on the beach. This sparked his fascination with ancient creatures. As he progressed through university, Howard became more focused on the early stages of Earth's history. He was particularly drawn to the origins of life and the earliest fossils. After completing his doctoral thesis, Howard faced uncertainty about his future. He applied for a job at Tavistock College in London, but wasn't sure if he would get it. The interview went ahead without the professor who was supposed to chair the panel, and Howard was surprised when he got the job. Months later, a colleague explained that the professor had been in a bad mood and had wanted to help Howard. Howard was relieved and grateful.

In his new role, Howard found that his professional life was structured and predictable, whereas his personal life was more chaotic. He often felt that external factors could affect his well-being. This was exemplified when his briefcase containing his lecture notes was stolen at an Underground station. Howard reported the theft and postponed his lecture. He then met a colleague who introduced him to a curator from the Natural History Museum in Nairobi. Howard learned about a newly acquired collection of fossils that needed to be studied and identified. This discovery would become his greatest challenge and secure his professional future. If the theft hadn't occurred, Howard might not have discovered this opportunity.

Charles Spence is a professor of experimental psychology at Oxford University in the UK. He's known for his unusual eating habits, and his office is filled with unusual food items, including ice cream made from bee larvae. This might sound strange, but Spence is actually a leading expert on how our senses work together to create the taste and smell of food. He has spent years studying how things like the company we keep, the way food is presented, and even the sounds we hear can affect what we eat.

Spence's work has had a significant impact on the food industry. He has worked with big food companies to develop new products and improve existing ones. He has also helped restaurants create menus that are more appealing to customers. For example, did you know that the person who orders first in a restaurant tends to enjoy their meal more than others? Or that we eat more when we're eating with others?

Spence's lab is not high-tech, but he has a lot of creative freedom because of his low overheads. He works with chefs and food companies to test new ideas and products. He has also helped big food brands reduce the amount of salt and sugar in their products. This is good for customers, as it helps them stay healthy.

Spence has also worked with famous chefs, including Heston Blumenthal, to create new and innovative dishes. For example, they created a dish called "The Sound of the Sea" that used sound to enhance the flavor of the food. Spence's research has also shown that music can affect how we perceive the taste of food. For example, higher-pitched music can make food taste sweeter, while lower-pitched music can make it taste bitter.

Spence's work has many applications, from the food industry to airlines and even smartphone apps. He has also found that shapes and colors can affect our perception of food, and that music can be used to enhance the dining experience. At home, Spence and his family like to have dinner parties with a twist, where they experiment with different flavors and sounds.<|eot_id|>

Our brains are constantly bombarded with information, including facts, rumors, and opinions. We need to sift through this information to find what's important and ignore what's not. At the same time, we're doing more things on our own, such as booking flights and making purchases online. We're doing the work of multiple people, but we're still expected to keep up with our personal and professional lives. Our smartphones are a big part of this, as we use them to manage our time and stay connected.

However, research suggests that multitasking is not as effective as we think it is. In reality, our brains are not designed to handle multiple tasks at once. Instead, we're constantly switching between tasks, which can lead to mental fatigue and decreased productivity. Multitasking can also increase stress and anxiety, as our brains are constantly seeking external stimulation.

The brain's prefrontal cortex is particularly vulnerable to distraction, making it difficult to focus on one task for an extended period. In fact, research has shown that even the opportunity to multitask can reduce cognitive performance. This is known as "info-mania," and it can have a significant impact on our ability to learn and retain new information.

For example, trying to focus on a task while checking email can reduce our IQ by almost 10 points. Learning new information while multitasking can also lead to poor retention, as our brains are not able to process information effectively. Furthermore, making decisions while multitasking can be particularly challenging, as it requires a significant amount of neural resources.

Overall, it's clear that our brains are not well-suited to handle the demands of modern life. We need to find ways to manage our time and attention more effectively, and prioritize what's truly important.<|eot_id|>

In a Swedish zoo, a chimpanzee named Santino spent his nights breaking up concrete to throw at visitors during the day. Was he being mean? In the US, female bats help other mothers find the right way to have their babies. Are they being kind? Fifty years ago, people thought animals just acted on instinct and didn't have feelings or moral values. But recently, scientists have started to study animal emotions. This has led to a debate about whether animals have consciousness, or the ability to think and feel. Some people think animals have a moral sense, or conscience, which guides their behavior. For example, in a recent experiment, cows that opened a gate to get food showed more joy than those who didn't. If cows enjoy problem-solving, what does this mean for eating beef? Some scientists think we should stop eating meat, while others think we should just learn more about animal cognition. The debate is not just about science, but also about philosophy. It's hard to define consciousness, so can we ever really know what it's like to be an animal? Researchers have even found evidence that starlings can get depressed when kept in small, dirty cages. Some scientists believe that animals have feelings and rights, and that we should treat them with respect. Others think we should be more careful not to anthropomorphise animals, or attribute human qualities to them. The debate is ongoing, and it's up to each individual to decide how to approach it.

'Critical thinking is the ability to understand and evaluate information in a deeper way. Adrian West, a researcher at the Edward de Bono Foundation, believes that technology can both help and hinder our ability to think critically. On one hand, technology provides us with a vast amount of information, which can be overwhelming. On the other hand, it can lead to a lack of critical thinking, as people are exposed to poor quality information and opinions. According to West, the abundance of information does not necessarily lead to better decision-making.

The National Endowment for the Arts has reported a decline in literary reading, which may be contributing to a decline in critical thinking. Patricia Greenfield, a professor of psychology, suggests that this decline may be due to the emphasis on visual media and multi-tasking, rather than focusing on a single task.

However, the impact of technology on critical thinking is not straightforward. While some technologies, such as video games, can promote critical thinking, others, such as real-time media, can hinder it. Greenfield's research shows that reading enhances critical thinking, while visual media can improve some types of information processing but not others.

James Paul Gee, a professor of educational psychology, argues that video games can be a valuable tool for learning and can even help build smarter children with better reasoning skills. Games like Sim City and Civilization teach decision-making and analytical skills in a virtual environment that resembles the real world.

In conclusion, the impact of technology on critical thinking is complex and multifaceted. It is essential to understand the subtleties of how technology affects our thinking and analysis in order to make the most of its benefits and mitigate its drawbacks.'

Matthew Crawford is a philosopher who writes about how we should live our lives. When he's not writing, he works as a motorcycle mechanic. His latest book is about how to cope with modern life. He was inspired to write it when he noticed how easily advertisements pop up on credit card machines. He realized that our attention is being constantly demanded, making it difficult to focus on what's important.

We're all becoming more aware of the constant distractions around us. We're being interrupted all the time, and it's making us close off and not want to interact with others. Crawford says that we're being manipulated by technology, which is designed to appeal to our desires. This is making us lose touch with the world around us.

Not everyone is worried about this, but studies have shown that even having a phone nearby can distract us. It's not just technology, though - our constant desire for choice and control is also a problem. We're choosing to communicate with each other through screens rather than face-to-face, which is affecting our social lives.

Crawford thinks that we need to find ways to engage with the world in a more meaningful way. He suggests that we should learn skills that require us to focus on the world around us, like cooking, playing sports, or riding a motorcycle. These activities help us develop our judgment and ability to work with others.

He also thinks that we need to find ways to manage distractions in public spaces and learn to focus on what's important. By doing so, we'll be able to pay attention to others and build stronger relationships.

"What do you do for a living?" This is a common question, and most people answer it easily. However, when I'm asked, I hesitate because I'm a philosopher. Saying you're a philosopher sounds pretentious, like you're claiming to have special knowledge or insight. But philosophers are just like everyone else - they're not special. So, why do people think philosophers are above the rest? One reason is that philosophers are often seen as judges, evaluating the actions of others and celebrating intellectual pursuits. The ancient Greek philosopher Aristotle believed that a life of contemplation was the most virtuous. Few modern philosophers agree, but the idea persists. Another Greek philosopher, Socrates, said that an unexamined life is not worth living. This means that a life that simply follows the crowd is unsatisfying. It's our ability to reflect on the world that allows us to make our own decisions. But this doesn't mean you need to be a bookworm or a genius. It means taking a closer look at your daily experiences and making sure they're meaningful. This doesn't have to be a life of isolation or detachment. In fact, it's a practical and essential part of living a good life.

There's another reason why people think philosophers are out of touch. Academic philosophy has become more specialized and removed from everyday life. Philosophers often write for each other, using technical language that's hard to understand. This makes it hard for non-experts to engage with philosophy. As a result, many people see philosophers as distant and irrelevant. But this isn't entirely the fault of philosophers. The university system and funding priorities contribute to this isolation. To change this, philosophers need to find ways to share their ideas with a broader audience.

I often describe myself as an ethicist, but I'm starting to think this title doesn't capture the full scope of my work. Ethics is often associated with formal codes and laws, but there's more to it. I explore the justice of social practices and help people think critically about their values and behaviors. Philosophy can help people examine their daily lives and make sense of the world. It's not just about abstract ideas; it's about making a difference in people's lives.

Food and philosophy have not always gone hand in hand. Historically, philosophers have used food as a metaphor to discuss other topics, such as the pursuit of knowledge. However, food is more than just a metaphor. It is a complex and multifaceted aspect of human experience that deserves philosophical attention.

Food is inherently social and cultural. The food we eat is shaped by our history and shared with others in our communities. This social aspect of food is often overlooked, but it is essential to understanding our relationship with food.

Philosophers have also neglected the sensory experience of eating. Tasting food is not a special expertise, but rather a skill that can be developed. In fact, the mechanisms underlying our perception of taste have not received much attention in philosophical literature.

Food is also an aesthetic experience. While we often describe paintings and music as beautiful, we rarely talk about the beauty of food. However, the rise of modern gastronomy has led some philosophers to argue that food deserves a place in aesthetic discourse alongside sculpture and poetry.

Ethical considerations are also important when it comes to food. Questions about what we should eat, such as whether it should be organic or locally grown, reveal our ethical beliefs. Philosophers will always ask why we make these choices and engage in debates about the ethics of food.

Finally, cooking in restaurants and at home raises different ethical considerations. Home cooks have a special duty to their guests, while professional cooks have obligations to their employers and the food itself. The way we cook and eat can also play a role in bridging cultural gaps, whether through learning to appreciate different cuisines or sharing meals with people from other cultures.

Rob Daviau, an American game designer, created 'legacy' board games. He thought traditional board games were no longer exciting or challenging enough. He wondered if games could have a storyline and if decisions made in one session could affect the next one. Daviau adapted the classic game Risk to create Risk Legacy, where players' decisions had a permanent impact. They might have to tear up cards, damage the board, or open new rule packets. The game takes place over several sessions, and players can point to the board and say, "You did this!"

Daviau collaborated on a legacy version of Pandemic, a popular cooperative game where players try to cure diseases. His next project was SeaFall, a game where players become seafarers exploring a new world. Legacy game designers must consider all possible player choices to ensure the story doesn't fall apart. They test the games with players to see how they unfold.

Daviau didn't expect legacy games to become mainstream. He thought it would be a niche idea. However, most players loved the concept, which they saw as a major innovation in game design. It offers a new level of commitment, excitement, and intensity. Players enjoy the experience of playing a new game every time, similar to watching a new episode of a TV series.

Pandemic creator Matt Leacock compared the legacy design process to writing a novel. You need to have an idea of how you want it to end and begin, but also be flexible. Daviau wants to see where others take the idea, but he's also aware that gamers might soon ask for something new.

Colby Dauch, the studio manager for SeaFall's publisher, thinks the legacy format has changed the way people think about board games.<|eot_id|>

One night, an octopus named Inky escaped from his tank at the New Zealand National Aquarium. He crawled across the floor and squeezed into a drain leading to the Pacific Ocean. This remarkable story was widely shared online. People love to imagine that animals are like us, and octopuses are especially fascinating because of their intelligence. They can open jars, recognize faces, use coconut shells as armor, and even play. Anthropomorphism is the tendency to attribute human-like qualities to animals. However, Dr. Frans de Waal, a primate expert, argues that it's not anthropomorphism, but rather a reluctance to accept that animals are capable of intelligent behavior, which is a common attitude towards other species.

Dr. de Waal analyzed decades of research on animal cognition and found that many animals exhibit intelligent behaviors, such as considering the past and future, showing empathy, and anticipating the actions of others. In other words, animals are much smarter than we often give them credit for. Dr. de Waal believes that this reluctance to recognize animal intelligence is a relatively modern phenomenon. In the past, animals were considered intelligent enough to be put on trial for crimes. Charles Darwin, the famous naturalist, even believed that the difference in mind between humans and animals is one of degree, not kind.

The rise of behaviorism in the 20th century led to a shift in public perception of animal intelligence. For most of the century, animals were seen as either stimulus-response machines or robots with useful instincts. Anyone who thought animals had internal lives was dismissed as romantic or unscientific. However, Dr. de Waal believes that we are now emerging from this period and recognizing that animal cognition is on the same spectrum as human intelligence, although not necessarily at the same level.

Dr. de Waal argues that the most effective tests of animal intelligence are designed with a species' unique traits and skills in mind. Squirrels may fail human memory tests, but they can remember where they hid their nuts. An octopus might test human intelligence by asking us to produce color patterns on our skin, and we would likely fail. Dr. de Waal remains skeptical about Inky's escape story, but he acknowledges the power of viral stories to raise awareness about animal intelligence. He even ran an experiment to test whether capuchin monkeys can experience envy, and the results were published in a scientific journal. However, it was a one-minute video clip of the experiment that really convinced people of the findings. This is just one example of the quirks of the human mind.

'The field of robotics is expected to be a revolutionary technological shift, comparable to the Industrial Revolution. While robots have been used in manufacturing and automotive industries for decades, experts predict a significant increase in their use across various sectors in the near future. Many people recognize the impact of robotic automation, but they underestimate its effects. According to a recent survey, two-thirds of people believe that robots will perform most human jobs in the next 50 years, while 80% think their current jobs will remain unchanged. However, this is unlikely. Every industry will be affected by robotic automation in the next few years. For example, an Australian company has developed a robot that can lay 1,000 bricks in one hour, a task that would take human bricklayers several days to complete.

Advocates of robotic automation highlight the potential for new, high-skilled jobs, while critics warn that the dehumanization of work could lead to social unrest. Dr. Jing Bing Zhang, a world expert on robotics, notes that the industry is rapidly evolving. His research team predicts that within two years, one-third of robots will be advanced enough to work alongside humans. Within three years, many companies will have a chief robotics officer, and governments will have implemented regulations. By five years, salaries in the robotics sector will increase by at least 60%, but there will be a shortage of skilled workers.

Zhang emphasizes the need for workers to adapt to changing job requirements and retrain themselves. He believes that the government cannot protect jobs from technology, and that individuals must take responsibility for their own career development.
